summary: In Book VIII, Marcus Aurelius emphasizes virtue as the foundation of a good life. He argues for simplicity, restraint, and returning to reason whenever the mind becomes scattered. Marcus urges himself to avoid excess, unnecessary emotion, and the temptation to live for approval or pleasure.

micro_lessons.title: Virtue Is the Only True Good
micro_lessons.core_idea: Marcus reminds himself that external successes mean nothing if not grounded in virtue.
micro_lessons.micro_test_q: What does Marcus consider the only true good?

micro_lessons.title: Live Simply
micro_lessons.core_idea: Marcus advocates cutting away luxuries and focusing on essentials.
micro_lessons.micro_test_a: Simple, restrained, and focused on essentials.

micro_lessons.title: Avoid Unnecessary Emotion
micro_lessons.core_idea: Most emotional reactions are exaggerated and unhelpful; reason must intervene.
micro_lessons.micro_test_a: Because they distort judgment and waste energy.

micro_lessons.title: Do Not Be Seduced by Applause
micro_lessons.core_idea: Praise means nothing unless you are truly living according to reason.

micro_lessons.title: Return to Yourself Often
micro_lessons.core_idea: Marcus urges repeated inward reflection to stay aligned with reason.
micro_lessons.micro_test_q: What should you return to frequently?

micro_lessons.title: Control Begins With Restraint
micro_lessons.core_idea: Saying no to impulses is the beginning of mastery.
micro_lessons.micro_test_q: What is the foundation of self-control?

micro_lessons.title: Avoid Overthinking Others’ Motives
micro_lessons.core_idea: People act based on their own beliefs and limitations, not because of you.
micro_lessons.micro_test_a: Because their actions reflect their own limitations, not your worth.

micro_lessons.title: Focus on What Truly Matters
micro_lessons.core_idea: Much of life’s noise distracts from meaningful work.
micro_lessons.micro_test_q: What should you ignore to stay focused?

micro_lessons.title: Speak Only What Is Necessary
micro_lessons.core_idea: Speech should be concise, truthful, and useful.

micro_lessons.title: Do Not Live for Pleasure
micro_lessons.core_idea: Pleasure is fleeting and often disrupts discipline.
micro_lessons.micro_test_a: Because it weakens discipline and focus.

micro_lessons.title: Choose Actions That Strengthen the Soul
micro_lessons.core_idea: Every choice either strengthens or weakens your character.

micro_lessons.title: Let Go of What You Cannot Control
micro_lessons.core_idea: Worrying about external events wastes energy that should be spent on duty.
micro_lessons.micro_test_q: Why release concerns about the external world?

micro_lessons.title: Align Actions With Rational Purpose
micro_lessons.core_idea: Reason, not impulse, should dictate behavior.

micro_lessons.title: Don’t Get Stuck in Past Harm
micro_lessons.core_idea: Resentment is a chain that holds the mind captive.
micro_lessons.micro_test_q: Why avoid dwelling on past harm?
micro_lessons.micro_test_a: Because it traps you in resentment.

micro_lessons.title: Cut Away the Inessential
micro_lessons.core_idea: Most of what occupies the mind is noise; reduce your inputs to increase clarity.
micro_lessons.micro_test_q: How can you improve mental clarity?

micro_lessons.title: Self-Correction Is a Strength
micro_lessons.core_idea: Marcus insists that correcting your mistakes immediately is a sign of wisdom, not weakness.

micro_lessons.title: Act Without Attachment
micro_lessons.core_idea: Do the right thing without needing a particular outcome.
